9.82.text: John Watson: Sherlock! We’ve received a letter,

12.94.text: in this day and age. How curious …

15.70.text: Sherlock Holmes: Yes John, about as curious

16.99.text: as a dog that doesn’t bark …

18.83.text: Hnh! Type-written, and with a dandy roll watermark

22.91.text: JW: Dear Mr Holmes, I wouldn’t bother you …

25.08.text: Mary Westmacott: … if I didn’t think my life was in danger.

30.43.text: It’s absurd, but I’m being haunted

35.27.text: I’m a screenwriter and was recently commissioned

39.12.text: a film about a missing boy.

43.30.text: and for once the contract terms were great:

45.67.text: a dream job that would pay the bills

47.70.text: for many years … but the dream has soured.

51.78.text: The problems began when I started fleshing out

57.23.text: A number of ideas presented themselves:

66.48.text: The others weren’t so well developed:

79.06.text: but just as I settled on one,

81.64.text: I started seeing the others everywhere I went

85.34.text: exactly as they were in my imagination,

90.87.text: It’s as if they simply willed themselves

95.81.text: I woke to the sound of someone at my typewriter

102.53.text: just a page with three unsettling words:

109.53.text: People tell me I’m going mad

111.21.text: but I know this is real;

113.18.text: Mr Holmes, I’m writing in the frantic hope …

116.77.text: JW: … that you can help me wake up

124.41.text: Sherlock, whoever heard of characters stepping

127.41.text: out of an author’s imagination and coming to life?

130.05.text: SH: John, quickly, find the number

131.73.text: get Ms. Westmacott on the phone.

133.13.text: I believe she’s in great danger.

135.12.text: SH: Don’t ‘what’ me John, just do it …

136.72.text: JW: Alright, alright … I don’t know.

141.71.text: SH: There’s something uncanny about all of this;

148.25.text: I’ll stake my reputation on her sanity!

150.50.text: No, this is the work of a good old-fashioned villain

153.50.text: a madman intent on driving Mary insane:

156.45.text: subverting her sense of fantasy and reality …

162.17.text: JW: Holmes, you won’t believe it!

164.32.text: SH: As I feared: she’s already dead.

169.39.text: she was murdered at her desk,

171.54.text: a dagger in her back, and three words

174.25.text: on the page in the typewriter:

179.67.text: The doors to the study were locked

181.53.text: from the inside, with no sign of forced entry.

184.80.text: And the manuscript for the film is gone!

192.97.text: Although it would appear that we have just

194.68.text: been engaged to work for a corpse.

196.77.text: Grab your coat John … the Game is On!
